questiontext.text:
A recently-graduated economist gets two job offers.

He can get a job in the US with a monthly salary of $5.000. The mean salary in the US equals $3.300 and the standard deviation is $800. He can also get a job in Germany with a monthly salary of €4.000. In Germany, the mean salary amounts to €2.800 and the standard deviation to €500.

In which country can he get the highest salary (compared to the mean salary in the country)? And how can you conclude this?

answer.text: In the US, because the standard error of the offered salary is higher in the US than in Germany
In Germany, because the z-score of the offered salary is higher in Germany than in the US.
In Germany, because the standar error of the offered salary is higher in Germany than in the US
In Germany, because the correlation coefficient of the offered salary is higher in Germany than in the US
In the US, because the correlation coeffecient of the offered salary is higher in the US than in Germany
In the US, because the z-score of the offered salary is higher in the US than in Germany
